title: RBAC: Add cache for oss rbac permissions
body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
We have had the option to use permissions cache in enterprise for a while. We did not add it to oss because at the time we had no permissions stored in the db. With managed permissions we do and should add the possibility to use it. This will respect the permission_cache setting.

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes**:
Fixes #

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
Enterprise pr https://github.com/grafana/grafana-enterprise/pull/3841

title: RBAC: Fix background users to include permissions

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
In https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/54910 we changed so that we short circuit the evaluate call if no permissions are set for the user. This broke some background users. Alerting user, fixed by https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/55127, recorded queries, fixed by https://github.com/grafana/grafana-enterprise/pull/3844 and PluginDashboard import.

This pr does two things. Add a new constructor for Background users and fixes the PluginDashboard user.

title: Prometheus: properly check for proxy mode

labels.name: pr/external
labels.description: This PR is from external contributor

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

body:
The original check has been added ~3 years ago and since then a new variable has been added that says whether the mode is browser or proxied.

Start using the new variable in this function so that proxy mode could be properly detected. It's important to us to get these headers and this check is currently broken for HTTP/HTTPS URLs.

Signed-off-by: Giedrius Statkevičius <giedrius.statkevicius@vinted.com>

title: Analytics: Add total queries and cached queries to metaanalytics
body:
<!--

Thank you for sending a pull request! Here are some tips:

1. If this is your first time, please read our contribution guide at https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md

2. Ensure you include and run the appropriate tests as part of your Pull Request.

3. In a new feature or configuration option, an update to the documentation is necessary. Everything related to the documentation is under the docs folder in the root of the repository.

4. If the Pull Request is a work in progress, make use of GitHub's "Draft PR" feature and mark it as such.

5. If you can not merge your Pull Request due to a merge conflict, Rebase it. This gets it in sync with the main branch.

6. Name your PR as "<FeatureArea>: Describe your change", e.g. Alerting: Prevent race condition. If it's a fix or feature relevant for the changelog describe the user impact in the title. The PR title is used to auto-generate the changelog for issues marked with the "add to changelog" label.

-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**: 
* adds total queries and cached queries to the `kv` map that we use for usage insights logs
* cloud users want to be able to ignore cached queries when looking at datasource query volume- this allows for better cost/load forecasting

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes**: 
* https://github.com/orgs/grafana/projects/129/

**Special notes for your reviewer**: 
* see my [last PR](https://github.com/grafana/grafana-enterprise/pull/3529) for an example of the JSON we're unpacking.

title: Panel: Disable legends when showLegend is false prior to schema v37

labels.name: backport v9.1.x
labels.description: Bot will automatically open backport PR

body:
<!--

Thank you for sending a pull request! Here are some tips:

1. If this is your first time, please read our contribution guide at https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md

2. Ensure you include and run the appropriate tests as part of your Pull Request.

3. In a new feature or configuration option, an update to the documentation is necessary. Everything related to the documentation is under the docs folder in the root of the repository.

4. If the Pull Request is a work in progress, make use of GitHub's "Draft PR" feature and mark it as such.

5. If you can not merge your Pull Request due to a merge conflict, Rebase it. This gets it in sync with the main branch.

6. Name your PR as "<FeatureArea>: Describe your change", e.g. Alerting: Prevent race condition. If it's a fix or feature relevant for the changelog describe the user impact in the title. The PR title is used to auto-generate the changelog for issues marked with the "add to changelog" label.

-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Because of the migration logic, if any schema older than v37 includes `showLegend: false` that value is ignored and fallen back to `true` since the accepted value is `displayMode === 'hidden'` for those versions. [This Mimir dashboard](https://github.com/grafana/mimir/blob/cacd7593458475964391ce27acf2f3059d290a6c/operations/mimir-mixin-compiled/dashboards/mimir-writes.json#L655-L679) is generated with that option which breaks the experience. To solve this, we will allow older versions of the schema to be able to use `showLegend` which is the actual way of toggling it.

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes**:
<!--

- Automatically closes linked issue when the Pull Request is merged.

Usage: "Fixes #<issue number>", or "Fixes (paste link of issue)"

-->

Fixes #54472

title: Alerting: Fix alerting evaluation to use proper permissions

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/54910 updated the permissions evaluator to shortcut the check if the user does not have any permissions. This change broke the evaluation of the rules in alerting engine because it uses a pseudo-user 

https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/b06eaf66b6077083d2353efcdd8c874697f128ad/pkg/services/ngalert/eval/eval.go#L194-L197

This PR does two things:
1. Updates the alerting rule evaluator to require user struct, and updates rule testing APIs to provide the real user instead of the fake one. This will reduce the probability of unauthorized access to a data source when alerting API authorization and data source permission requirements are out of sync.
2. Updates the scheduler to provide the pseudo-user with enough permissions to query the data sources.

title: Add start time and end time parameters while querying tempo traces

labels.name: pr/needs-manual-testing
labels.description: Before merge some help with manual testing & verification is requested

labels.name: pr/external
labels.description: This PR is from external contributor

body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Recently https://github.com/grafana/tempo added start and end timestamp to /api/traces API via https://github.com/grafana/tempo/pull/1388. This is done to make the searches faster  by scanning only the blocks within the start and end time. We want to consume the parameters so that the start and end timestamps are supplied from Grafana.

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
Aligning this PR with @joe-elliott. I hope this PR satisfies the requirements that was mentioned in https://github.com/grafana/tempo/issues/1373. The timestamps will be the range of the search query given by the user.

cc: @sagarwala, @ashwinidulams

title: plugins: Introduce generated, static core plugin registry

labels.name: area/schema
labels.description: Related to canonical Grafana entity schemas

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

body:
<!--

Thank you for sending a pull request! Here are some tips:

1. If this is your first time, please read our contribution guide at https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md

2. Ensure you include and run the appropriate tests as part of your Pull Request.

3. In a new feature or configuration option, an update to the documentation is necessary. Everything related to the documentation is under the docs folder in the root of the repository.

4. If the Pull Request is a work in progress, make use of GitHub's "Draft PR" feature and mark it as such.

5. If you can not merge your Pull Request due to a merge conflict, Rebase it. This gets it in sync with the main branch.

6. Name your PR as "<FeatureArea>: Describe your change", e.g. Alerting: Prevent race condition. If it's a fix or feature relevant for the changelog describe the user impact in the title. The PR title is used to auto-generate the changelog for issues marked with the "add to changelog" label.

-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:

This PR introduces a static, codegen'd plugin registry for core plugins. It is a follow-up to #53754, which introduced the `pfs` package that scans and validates an `io/fs` containing plugin meta files (`plugin.json` and `models.cue`). Basically, we get a central static registry of `*pfs.Tree`, one for each core plugin, that can be imported by external repositories, and is kept up to date invisibly and automatically every time anyone runs `make gen-cue`. (And in CI.)

Most surprising for folks will be that this PR introduces Go files under `public/app/plugins`, which historically has been a frontend-only area. There are two basic reasons for doing this:

* It steps up the approach of treating core plugins the same as external plugins begun in #53754.
* It's the simplest possible approach.

The union of these facts means that codegen won't need to change much when we write similar functionality into tools for external plugins. (c.f. this [design doc section](https://docs.google.com/document/d/12vYU-DRlS0yYxvXW52cOH7kSIxmJAER_4_mlA0An_QM/edit#heading=h.elk2cypppbnb)) More details in [this slack thread](https://raintank-corp.slack.com/archives/C01C4K8DETW/p1659430436734929) and linked threads, if any Grafanistas care to dig in.

Once again, there's a lot of changes in here. I'll break it down by path pattern in decreasing order of significance for reviewers:

* `pkg/plugins/pfs/registry/*`: a combination statically populated and handwritten "registry" of core plugins, with particular focus on looking up lineages by slot. As with the `pfs` package in the prior PR, i'm hoping this is useful for the overall plugins system going forward - i.e., `registry.List` can represent `*pfs.Tree`s that come from external plugins just as easily as the core ones.
* `public/app/plugins/*/*/pfs_gen.go`: Embeds the `plugin.json` for that plugin and makes it available in Go via a func named `PluginTree()`. References to each plugin's generated `PluginTree()` func are what's generated into `pkg/plugins/pfs/registry`.
  * If the plugin contains a `models.cue`, that's also embedded, and standard Thema LineageFactory functions are generated to get at the lineage. (`*pfs.Tree` serves our needs though so we don't use them; i may ultimately choose to not to generate them at all.)
* `pkg/codegen/pluggen.go`: the meat of the new codegen logic, which produces everything else of substance in this PR.
* `pkg/codegen/**` (others): codegen framework refactoring. Really needed to do this to make all this feasible. I could try to separate it out, but it would be a PITA - it would be amazing if kind reviewers could just ignore it.

Everything else not in this list is noise related to the codegen refactor. It improves, or at least makes consistent, a lot of comments - but ultimately nothing that impacts behavior. (`pkg/codegen` is rapidly moving towards a framework. On balance, that's a good thing, even if it means noise right now!)

Merging this PR completes most of [pass 4 of the schematization design](https://docs.google.com/document/d/12vYU-DRlS0yYxvXW52cOH7kSIxmJAER_4_mlA0An_QM/edit#heading=h.sc1cwrlnanla). What remains is composition in Thema itself (basically item 2 on my TODO list now), and implementing the 'dist' registry. I didn't bother with the latter because it's not strictly necessary for me to do codegen in grok. Which is what's next - taking the generated registry here, along with the existing coremodel registry, and getting grok properly ready for public use.

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

Note that everything here also works for datasource plugins, though none of the datasource plugins are converted yet.

Currently, we do not generate Go types for panel plugins. That's because i haven't yet dealt with converting [imports of our special CUE package](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/4dbe0b4f025f65e07b168f306def5683356fb5d1/public/app/plugins/panel/barchart/models.cue#L19) to a Go equivalent.

We _do_ generate types for datasource plugins, but since no datasource plugins have implemented schema yet, i've made [this gist](https://gist.github.com/sdboyer/4f79e228fd5c1e9924b970c8ba60510b) to illustrate. That's also worth having a look at because it shows how this whole system behaves in the presence of multiple slot implementations/lineages, which we have for datasources. (Yes, there's a bug with generating Go code for `DSOptions`, but IMO it can be fixed in a follow-up)

Note that there really isn't an equivalent to the generated `coremodel.Interface` (e.g. [here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/coremodel/pluginmeta/pluginmeta_gen.go#L564-L584)) for plugins. The closest thing is `*pfs.Tree` and just plain old `"github.com/grafana/thema".Lineage` itself. I think that's good enough for us to start with.

title: AzureMonitor: Explain custom and metric namespace properties

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

labels.name: backport v9.1.x
labels.description: Bot will automatically open backport PR

body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
If there is only one namespace returned _and_ it matches the namespace in the query, don't render the namespace selector.

I can't think of a situation where a user would want to manually enter a namespace since it wouldn't work if it's not one of the returned namespaces.

I also added a comment to the `customNamespace` property since it's undocumented and weird.

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes**:
Fixes #54999

title: PublicDashboards: Dont support exemplars
body:
**Problem**
Exemplars are handled within the Prometheus datasource on the frontend. There's a lot of code that handles those transformations, and currently, it's low priority to add exemplar support for our `PublicDashboardDatasource`.

**Solution**
When gathering queries on the backend for public dashboards, we remove the exemplar property if it exists.

**Notes**
I moved the dashboard_queries into the publicdashboards service because they're only used for public dashboards.

fixes https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/54035

title: Plugins: Use error plane for api/ds/query
body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes**:
Ref #54664

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

**Questions/concerns:**
- Convention for message id's? `shorturl.bad-request` vs `shorturl.badRequest`
- Public payload - add `Error.WithPublicPayload`?
- Log key/value pairs/internal payload - something to add? I guess we don't want to generate log messages that includes non-unique strings, e.g. includes user id or similar?
- Better fallback in response.go? 
  - https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/7779ae315b6e5e1217ffd38cc31a1f704bdd8440/pkg/api/response/response.go#L232
  - Tricky when migrating services that uses multiple other services and returning `response.Err` and you only want to migrate one service at a time. Any recommendations?
- If you have static errors you always have to call `Errorf`? Could we define a method on `Base` to create a static `Error` or something?
 -  Now we're keeping internal errors in the plugin packages and maps those errors to `errutil.Base` errors before returning them to the client, does this make sense?
 - https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/33dc7aed0a76a4756291cb21a398e84e6b7632f8/pkg/plugins/manager/client/client.go#L29-L32

title: PublicDashboards: UI improvements
body: **What this PR does / why we need it**: makes an improvement for PubDash modal UI. - Sentence case capitalization in texts - Spacing between checkboxes modified to be a VerticalGroup, instead of br tag - Time range input modified to be DateTime picker component - DateTime picker and switch components rendered on the right **Which issue(s) this PR fixes**: Fixes https://github.com/grafana/grafana-partnerships-team/issues/342 **Special notes for your reviewer**:

title: Search: Avoid requesting all dashboards when in Folder View

labels.name: backport v9.1.x
labels.description: Bot will automatically open backport PR

body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:

Someone complained that the folder search seemed slower since upgrading to 9, after investigating we figured out that the folder view was making an unnecessary search. These are the requests it makes on load of that view:
- Request ALL dashboards
- Request all folders
- 1 request per expanded folder to request the dashboards in that folder

That first request is unnecessary and never used. It is done because the search input is empty, so it requests all dashboards, but the result is only used if in list view. This PR stops that request from happening.

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes**:

Fixes part of https://github.com/grafana/support-escalations/issues/3857

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

Someone who helped implement search should double check if my assumption that the request is not used is correct, as search is a bit confusing and I'm not too familiar

title: Alerting: New API endpoint GET /api/v1/ngalert
body:
<!--

Thank you for sending a pull request! Here are some tips:

1. If this is your first time, please read our contribution guide at https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md

2. Ensure you include and run the appropriate tests as part of your Pull Request.

3. In a new feature or configuration option, an update to the documentation is necessary. Everything related to the documentation is under the docs folder in the root of the repository.

4. If the Pull Request is a work in progress, make use of GitHub's "Draft PR" feature and mark it as such.

5. If you can not merge your Pull Request due to a merge conflict, Rebase it. This gets it in sync with the main branch.

6. Name your PR as "<FeatureArea>: Describe your change", e.g. Alerting: Prevent race condition. If it's a fix or feature relevant for the changelog describe the user impact in the title. The PR title is used to auto-generate the changelog for issues marked with the "add to changelog" label.

-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:
When Grafana alerting user chooses to send Grafana-managed alerts to an external Alertmanager the information in the tab `Alert Group` (when Grafana source is selected) can be confusing because it reflects the status of the local Alertmanager that does not receive any alerts (due to the settings mentioned above). Also, for non-admin users that do not have access to the configuration that mentions the selection of the external Alertmanager the tabs like "Notification Policies", "Contact Points", "Silences" can be confusing because changes made in those tabs will not be applied to the external Alertmanager. 

Therefore, UI should notify users when Grafana alerts are sent to external Alertmanager. At this moment, there is no API endpoint that would be available to regular (non-admin) users and could provide the necessary information. This PR introduces a new endpoint `GET /api/v1/ngalert` that is available to any users that have any alerting read permissions. For now, it returns just a simple JSON object 
```
{
    "alertmanagersChoice": "internal"|"external"|"all"
}
```
and later can be expanded to provide some general information about the alerting engine (for example, available data sources that UI can query for alert rules)

Fixes: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/51321

### Changelog
- Alerting: Introduced a new API endpoint `GET /api/v1/ngalert` that returns the status\configuration of the alerting engine

title: PublicDashboards: Log api layer errors and which datasources fail/succeed
body:
**What this does**
1. All errors that bubble up in the public dashboards api get logged under the `publicdashboard.api` logger.

2. All pubdash datasources get their success status logged by the pubdash service.
For example, a success log would look like this:
`INFO [09-12|15:58:45] Successfully queried datasources for public dashboard logger=publicdashboards.service datasources=[prometheus]`

**Why we need it**
The current error logs (the context logger that logs all responses) don't have everything we need to give us context around the error that occurred. These changes give us a little more context to what went wrong and the endpoint on the service that was responsible.

We don't have an exhaustive list of datasources that pubdash works with (or doesnt work with). This will let us gather data on which datasources fail and which succeed.

fixes https://github.com/grafana/grafana-partnerships-team/issues/355
